claim.text: California Building Code Chapter 7A, developed after repeated catastrophic WUI fires, establishes ignition-resistant construction standards
claim.claim: California Building Code Chapter 7A establishes ignition-resistant construction standards for WUI areas

results.summary: California Building Code Chapter 7A does establish ignition-resistant construction standards for wildland-urban interface (WUI) areas.
results.detail: Chapter 7A of the California Building Code, titled 'Materials and Construction Methods for Exterior Wildfire Exposure,' establishes requirements for ignition-resistant construction in State Responsibility Areas and designated Local Agency Very High Fire Hazard Severity Zones. It was developed after California's devastating 1991 Oakland Hills fire and subsequent WUI fires, and has been updated multiple times since its initial adoption around 2005. The code specifies requirements for roofing, exterior walls, vents, decking, and other building components to resist wildfire ignition.
sources: California Building Standards Commission - California Building Code Chapter 7A
CAL FIRE - Building in the Wildland Urban Interface

claim.text: Class A fire-rated roofing, non-combustible or ignition-resistant exterior walls within specified distances, ember-resistant vents with 1/8-inch or smaller mesh, and enclosed eaves
claim.claim: California Building Code Chapter 7A requires ember-resistant vents with 1/8-inch or smaller mesh

results.summary: California Building Code Chapter 7A does require ember-resistant vents, but the mesh sizing requirements are more nuanced than stated.
results.detail: Chapter 7A of the California Building Code (Section 708A) does address venting requirements in wildfire-prone areas. The code requires vents to resist ember intrusion, but the specific mesh requirements include provisions for 1/16-inch mesh (not just 1/8-inch) for certain vent types, and some code updates have refined these requirements. The claim of '1/8-inch or smaller' is directionally correct but may not capture the full technical specification, which varies by vent location and type. Without current web access to verify the exact current code language, I cannot confirm the precise specification.

claim.text: Screen all vents — soffit vents, gable vents, foundation vents — with 3-millimeter or smaller corrosion-resistant metal mesh
claim.claim: 3-millimeter or smaller mesh is the recommended/required standard for ember-resistant vent screening

results.summary: The 1/8-inch (approximately 3.175mm) mesh standard is well-established for ember-resistant vents, though some codes specify different sizes and requirements vary by jurisdiction.
results.detail: California Building Code Chapter 7A and the International Wildland-Urban Interface Code specify 1/8-inch (3.175mm) mesh for vent openings in wildfire-prone areas. However, some sources recommend 1/16-inch mesh for superior ember protection. The claim of '3-millimeter or smaller' is slightly imprecise since the standard is 1/8-inch (3.175mm), not exactly 3mm. Additionally, recent California code updates (2020) have moved toward requiring ember-resistant vents that meet ASTM E2886 testing standards rather than just mesh size specifications.
